results.title: Let's hear it for the girls
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Belinda and ACMI
results.brief_description: Belinda pays tribute to her gang of girlfriends, whom she met at age 12. Fifteen years on, life has changed, but the ‘girls’ are still always there for each other.

results.title: Let's have a holiday
results.brief_description: Join the Silly Billies as they go on holiday to an amazing place called FUN FUN FUN. Once there you’ll see the Ashton Super Acrobats, play games and dance and sing. Songs on the video include: “The Water safety song”, “The Silly Billies song”, “Fun fun fun”, “The Boogie Woogie”, “Aussie rap”, “Miranda the Aussie kangaroo”, “The Electric crocodile”, “Dick the duck”, “Boxo the fox”, “Raise your hands and be happy”, “We can count to 20”, “Making up my milkshake” and “Ophelia the fairy”. Swimming coach Laurie Lawrence leads the children in “The Water safety song”.

results.title: Let's go to the movies
results.creator_credit: RKO Radio Pictures and Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences
results.brief_description: Presents a general picture of the background, development and technical advances of the motion picture industry throughout the years. Shows stars and scenes from milestones of film history including Mary Pickford in “The Hills of Old Kentucky”, Charlie Chaplin in “Easy Street”, “The Great Train Robbery” the beginnings of the newsreel, the genesis of sound as exemplified by Al Jolson in “The Jazz Singer” and classical music from “Night Song”.

results.title: Let's go to Birmingham
results.brief_description: A train ride with a difference - at an equivalent speed of 960 m.p.h. Timelapse photography is used to record the Blue Pullman run from London to Birmingham to a musical background of Strauss’s “Perpetuum Mobile”. Time lapse sequences of the complicated track in front of the Pullman are photographed from the driver’s window and inter-cut with contrasting glimpses of the passengers taken at normal speed. Photography by Jack West. This film is an up-to-date version of an earlier film “London to Brighton in Four Minutes” (Title Code 006440) produced for television by the BBC.

results.title: Let's go sailing. No.2. The Racing rules
results.creator_credit: Town and Country Productions and Bill Latto
results.brief_description: Illustrates the main rules of yacht racing as laid down by the IYRU in a specially devised race between five class dinghies. Some incidents are explained in detail.

results.title: Let's go sailing. No. 1
results.creator_credit: Town and Country Productions and Bill Latto
results.brief_description: Two people learn the elements of dinghy sailing and seamanship with expert instructors at a sailing school. The first lessons are given in Albacore, a National Firefly and a National Enterprise. When the rudiments have been learned they progress to an Ocean Racer.

results.title: Let's Go Sailing
results.brief_description: Australia 11’s coaching consultant and the 1984 Australian Olympic sailing coach, Mike Fletcher, introduces us to boatcraft and the elements of sailing. He presents the full range of basic knowledge necessary to enable us to take a sail boat onto the water.

results.title: Let's go riding
results.creator_credit: Town and Country Productions and Bill Latto
results.brief_description: The progress story of a father and daughter whose visit to a riding school decides them to take up riding. As a result of further training at a pony club and a riding club they reach a sufficient standard to consider specialising in dressage, show jumping and cross country. The film also contains examples of top grade riding at national and international events.

results.title: Let's go gliding
results.brief_description: For centuries mankind has admired the soaring eagle and the effortless flight of the gull. While some aeronautical engineers perfect jumbo-jets and space probes, others continue to improve gliders for the sport of soaring. There is no cheaper form of flying. The fuel is solar energy, the motive forces are the thermal air currents triggered by the sun’s rays. Call it sport, or just plain enjoyment, it is an emulation of the bird. This is a celebration of soaring from the viewpoint of real people who are involved in the sport. Narrated by Ian Roache.
